text: THE MAIN AND CREDIT TITLES ARE IMPOSED ON a mezzotint of Edinburgh castle viewed from the Causeway.  When the last credit title dissolves
STOP FRAME of STOCK SHOT showing Edinburgh castle.  Over is a title:
With the DISSOLVE of the words the stock shot comes to li with a carriage coming toward the CAMERA.

FULL SPOT -- Down the lonely, almost deserted street come cab drawn by a bony white horse.  This black and sepulchr vehicle passes through the long shadows and sharp gleams the late afternoon sun.  On the box, bunched over, almost lost in the folds of his triple-caped overcoat and with a battered beaver on his hand, is the cabman.  The horse pl along, his hoof beats echoing with a hollow sound in the narrow street.  At the corner the vehicle turns left.

The black cab drawn by the white horse goes slowly past a little cemetery.  The driver turns his head and looks dow he goes past. From his ANGLE, but not a MOVING SHOT, a pleasant little graveyard with mossy gravestones; old turf making a spot green between the gray walls of the kirk and the blank st wall of a large building. Seated on a table stone is young Donald Fettes, a poor medical student, dressed in worn neat clothing with only woolen scarf about his neck for warmth.  He sits in such scanty sunlight as he can find, munching on a cold bannoc and washing it down with thin ale from a round stone bott MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes.  In the closer view it can be that he is looking at a small Cairn terrier who lies moro guarding a newly-made grave.  The dog, with his head down between his forepaws, occasionally glances over apprehensively at the young student.  Fettes takes a bit his bannock between his thumb and forefinger and leans forward toward the dog.
Here, -- here's a bit of something for you.

The dog does not stir.  Fettes leans further forward almo putting the morsel of food to the dog's nose.  The dog gr savagely.  Fettes draws back. FETTES (cont'd) Now, now, laddie -- I only wanted to be friendly.

It is at this moment that a shadow falls athwart him and looms up in the afternoon sunlight against the wall behin him.  He looks up. ANOTHER ANGLE -- Fettes looking over as Mrs. MacBride, a plump, motherly woman of middle-age, with a Tartan shawl her head and carrying a pannikin of water and a bone with some meat on it, comes through the gate.  She crosses ove the little dog, puts the water before him and starts shredding little pieces of meat from the bone to feed him The dog laps avidly at the water, then gratefully takes t morsels of meat she gives him. MED. FULL SHOT -- Fettes and Mrs. MacBride.
He'll not leave the grave -- not since Wednesday last when we buried the lad.
Your son, ma'am?  He must have been a fine boy for the wee dog to love him so.
Mrs. MacBride nods.
A great, kind lad, he was -- gentle with all things like Robbie.
She pauses, sighs and then goes on. MRS. MACBRIDE (cont'd) Now I can't get the dog to leave, here.  Perhaps it is for the best.  I've not money enough to afford a grave watcher.
(looking about) Not much danger here, ma'am, I wouldn't think -- right here in the heart of Edinburgh.
They're uncommon bold, the grave robbers -- and the daft doctors who drive them on.
(a little uncomfortable; feeling he has to make the admission) I'm by way of being a medical myself.
A doctor?
A student.  I'm studying under Dr. MacFarlane -- that is, I've been studying until today --

He starts to get up.  At this moment in the street can be heard the clop-clop of a horse's hoofs and the rattle of wheels on the cobblestones.  On the ground and gravestone appears and passes the monstrous shadow of a horse and ca angular and distorted, the driver's shadow hunched and ev now going from left to right.

LONG SHOT -- a typical street scene of the time.  A dog c drawn by a smart tandem passes.  It is driven by a young of the period; top-hatted, dandified, his whip held at a so angle.  On the sidewalk, a group of small boys follow recruiting sergeant of the Seaforth Highlanders.  A drumm walks at his heels.  He stops at a wooden "Charlie", the rough police booth of that day, and begins to tack up his posters.  The boys crowd around to watch.  One of them ba up to a little trundle cart and surreptitiously filches a piece of the shortbread being sold from this portable sto At the other side of the "Charlie" stands a street singer beautiful girl of about nineteen, dressed in ragged Highl plaid.  She is singing an old border ballad about two cro who sit waiting to pick the dead eyes out of a fallen kni A shepherd, crook in hand, and faithfully attended by two handsome collies, stops a moment to hear her song, drops coppers into the begging bowl she holds in her hands, the passes on. Through the consonance of the street singer's song comes dissonant beat of a horse's hoofs, the racking clatter of iron-shod wheels and then between the singer and the CAME there passes, very close, the white horse and the black c As it blocks her out of the scene

FULL SHOT -- Before the imposing edifice which houses Dr. MacFarlane's living quarters as well as his school of anatomy, the cab, drawn by the white horse, pulls up.  Th driver begins to alight from the box.  He climbs down, an starts for the cab door. CLOSE SHOT -- Gray as he opens the door.  Gray is a man o middle years with keen, darting eyes set in a face lined furrowed by an evil life.  The quick play of his features he talks or smiles can form a moving and deceptive mask. that now as he opens the door, smiling, to help his passengers alight, his face is cringing with good humor a servility. From the cab steps a young and lovely woman dressed in becoming widow's weeds.  This is Mrs. Marsh.  She reaches sidewalk, turns back for the other occupant of the cab. is a little girl of about eight, dressed in a flower-spri Kate Greenway gown and a poke bonnet to match.  Gray forestalls her.
I'll get it, ma'am.

He touches his hat respectfully, reaches in and brings ou tiny wheel-chair, which he sets down.  He reaches in agai and takes the child up in his arms. GRAY (cont'd) (as he picks her up) Come, little miss.  Cabman Gray'll carry you safe enough.

With the child in his arms he starts toward his horse's h talking as he goes. GRAY (cont'd) Give my horse a pat.  He knows every little girl in Edinburgh.  Some day when you're runnin' and playin' in the street he'll nicker at ye as we go by.
CLOSE SHOT -- The horse, Gray, and the little girl.
I can't run and play.
I'd forgotten that, lassie.  All the more reason for Friend here bidding you a good-day.
Georgina smiles and pats the horse's nose. ANOTHER ANGLE -- Featuring Mrs. Marsh as she smiles watch Gray and the child.  He turns back toward her.
Would you mind carrying her up the steps?

Mrs. Marsh reaches for the wheel-chair. FULL SHOT -- Mrs. Marsh takes the wheel-chair up the two steps.  Gray follows carrying the child.  He sets the chi tenderly in the wheel-chair, smiling as he does so.
Back in your own wee cab.
Thank you.

In the meantime, Mrs. Marsh has fumbled through her purse change.  She hands this to Gray.  He takes the money from right hand, then removes his hat with his left hand, bobs forelock with the right in a series of obsequious gesture
Thank ye, ma'am.  Thank ye. (to Georgina) You watch sharp, little miss for my horse to give you a "hello".
CLOSE SHOT -- Georgina looking at Gray with great pleased eyes.  This has made a definite impression on her.
Mrs. Marsh has used the door knocker.  Now in response th door is opened by a handsome woman of thirty-five, Meg Cameron.
I would like to see Dr. MacFarlane.

Meg gives Mrs. Marsh a quick look and then turns to look Gray.  A glance passes between them; a glance which tells previous acquaintance, yet neither speaks.  He turns and down the steps.  Silently, Meg opens the door and allows Marsh to push Georgina's wheel chair through into the hal

Georgina's wheel chair is pushed into this gloomy and forbidding entry.  Meg closes the door behind them, then without further word, strides down the hall.  Mrs. Marsh the little girl wait and look around. CLOSE SHOT -- Georgina.  With great wide eyes the child l around at the antlered stag head, the cruel-looking walki sticks in the umbrella stand and the light-footed Mercury with caduceus upraised.  The caduceus throws its patterne shadow across the child's face. CLOSE TWO SHOT -- Georgina and Mrs. Marsh.  Mrs. Marsh se the fright in the child's face and reassuringly pats her shoulder.  There is the sound of a door opening and they look off in that direction. MED. FULL SHOT -- The doorway to the sitting room, SHOOTI PAST Georgina and her mother.  Framed in this doorway is tall, robust figure of Dr. Douglas MacFarlane, a man in t prime of life, dressed with almost flamboyant foppishness carrying himself with the assurance that the world is not only his oyster, but that he has it pinned on a fork and swallow it and digest it with pleasure. THREE SHOT -- Georgina, Mrs. Marsh and Dr. MacFarlane.
(rising) Dr. MacFarlane?
He half-bows in acknowledgment. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) I'm Mrs. Marsh -- this is my daughter -- Georgina.

She fumbles in her reticule and pulls forth an unsealed letter which she passes to the doctor. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) Dr. Maximillian of Leyden asked me to present this to you.  He thought you might examine my little girl.
While she is speaking, Dr. MacFarlane has opened the miss
(as he reads) Maximillian -- a very famous colleague of mine.  I'm delighted to honor his request.

With an expansive gesture he points to a door.  Mrs. Mars pushes the wheel chair toward the living room door. DOLLY SHOT -- the entrance to the sitting room. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (over the child's head to Mrs. Marsh) Born paralyzed?
The little girl shrinks from him at the bluntness of this question.
No.  It was an accident.

Although it is late afternoon the lamps have been lit in part of the house.  Mrs. Marsh wheels the chair into the middle of the room and then stands to one side so that Dr MacFarlane can examine the child.  Meg Cameron stands by window.
Was the paralysis immediate?
No, Doctor.  She seemed to get better, then about six months later she began to complain of pain in her back --
How long after that was the paralysis complete?
Nearly a year.
Any attacks of pain since?
Yes, Doctor.
Is her pain sporadic or constant?
It comes at intervals.  They used to be months apart -- but they've been growing more frequent -- (catch in her voice) much more frequent.
(directly to Georgina) See here, child, when you have this pain in your back, where is it?
(setting her jaw) I don't know.
Point to where it hurts.  You can at least do that, can't you?
I don't know.
(angrily to Mrs. Marsh) This is useless, ma'am.
He leaves the sentence unfinished and goes toward the cen of the room.  Mrs. Marsh leans down beside the chair. TWO SHOT -- Mrs. Marsh and Georgina.
Please, darling, don't be so stubborn.
Georgina darts a glance in MacFarlane's direction.
(whispering) Mother -- he frightens me.

MED. FULL SHOT -- the door in the background.  There is a soft rap at the door and then almost immediately it opens Fettes comes in.  He looks about, sees the doctor busily engaged with a beautiful young woman and a sick child.  H embarrassed and tries to withdraw.
Excuse me, Dr. MacFarlane --
Come in, boy -- come in.

Fettes closes the door behind him and stands rather shyly not knowing what to do or say. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Perhaps you can do something with this young lady.  I can't get an aye, yes, or no out of her.
(protesting) But, Doctor, I only wanted to speak to you --
(interrupting) Come -- it's a chance to try out your bedside manner, Fettes.  Take a look at the child.
Fettes walks up shyly to the child. TWO SHOT -- Fettes and Georgina.  Fettes stands abashed a awkward before the clear-eyed glance of the little invali He smiles at her.  The child smiles back.
Are you a doctor, too?
Not yet.
You'll be a good doctor.  I know all about doctors.
Fettes smiles.
That's a nice chair you have.
He pushes it.  It rolls a little. FETTES (cont'd) Useful, too.  Where did you get it?  It isn't English, is it?
(studying him) What you really want to ask me is about my back, isn't it -- about where it hurts?
Why, yes.
Well --

She leans forward and reaches around with one hand. GEORGINA (cont'd) It's sort of all around here -- then down my legs -- it aches as if I had been walking an awfully long way -- (looking up at Fettes) That's funny, isn't it -- because I can't walk at all.
Would you mind very much if I lifted you -- (pointing to a table in the other room) -- onto that table in there?

She holds out her arms to him.  Fettes lifts her up and carries her into the other room. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal Mrs. Marsh and MacFarlane watching Fettes and the child.  They stand in the f.g. talking together while in the other room Fettes puts the child down on her stomach, opens her dress and examines h
Child seems to take to the lad.  What sort of an accident was it, Ma'am?
A carriage overturned.  My husband was killed and Georgina was hurt.
How long ago?
Three years.
(calling from the other room) Dr. MacFarlane --
(to Mrs. Marsh) Excuse me.
He strides forward.  Mrs. Marsh remains where she is.

MacFarlane comes into the scene, bends over and examines little girl's back.  He feels the spine with first one ha then the other.  He nods to Fettes and turns away.  Fette begins to button up the little girl's dress.

MacFarlane is walking back to where Mrs. Marsh stands.  I the b.g. Fettes can be seen as he buttons up the little girl's dress, picks her up in his arms and brings her bac the wheel chair.  MacFarlane comes over to Mrs. Marsh. TRUCKING SHOT of MacFarlane.
Meg, give Fettes a hand there -- help him wheel the little girl into the hall.

He turns back to Mrs. Marsh. TWO SHOT -- Mrs. Marsh and MacFarlane.  She is looking at anxiously; waiting to hear his verdict.  He glances at Dr Maximillian's letter before speaking. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (tapping the letter in his hand) It seems that Dr. Maximillian is right.  The violence of the accident must have disturbed the tissues and caused a traumatic tumor -- a sort of growth that presses against the nerve centers.
But can anything be done for her?
Perhaps -- a delicate operation -- an operation which has never been performed -- but it could be performed.  I'm sure it could be -- I could incise the columna dorsi --
He is quite excited as he speaks, almost as if challengin himself.  Mrs.  Marsh's interruption is ill-timed.  It st him in full tide of self-persuasion.
(eagerly) And you will try -- you will operate?
CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane.  He is silent; thinking. MED. FULL SHOT.  MacFarlane silently turns away from Mrs. Marsh and goes to his desk.  Having reached it, he turns faces her again.
Not I, Madame.
She starts toward him impulsively as if to plead with him
But, Doctor, in Leyden -- in Paris  - wherever I've taken Georgina -- they've mentioned your name.  I've come to think of you as our only hope.
MacFarlane looks at her, takes a step closer to her and speaks very sincerely.
Believe me, Madame, if I were only a doctor, I would undertake this operation at once.  But I'm more dominie than doctor -- I've a school to run.
But, Doctor, surely in a case like this -- a child -- a little child who can never walk or run --
I regret it, Ma'am, but I have the responsibility of training thirty other doctors to attend a thousand children like your own.
There's nothing I can say for one small child?

I'm not heartless, Ma'am.  I have every sympathy for you and for the little girl, but if I were to consent to every operation brought to me, I'd have no time for teaching -- and that's a great responsibility upon me, Ma'am -- a great responsibility.

They have reached the door.  He bows in dismissal, and Mr Marsh exits.  As she leaves, Fettes passes her coming fro the hallway. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane as he turns back into the r MACFARLANE (cont'd) (to Fettes) Well, Fettes -- what was it you wanted to see me about?
MED. TWO SHOT -- Fettes and MacFarlane.
(shyly) I'm afraid I'll have to give up medicine, Dr. MacFarlane.
(booming) You're made for a doctor, young man!
I'm afraid I have to, sir.  You see, my father is vicar at Thrums -- it's a small parish -- not much of a living --

(after thinking this over a moment; very sincerely) You're too good a man, Fettes -- I'll not let you quit. (with a sudden thought) I'll make an assistant of you -- that'll pay your keep and your tuition, too --
I thought only the best students were made assistants.
Well? And are you not a good student?
(getting the idea) But Richardson?
Richardson is a fine student.  He's got a glib tongue, but you'll be a better doctor, Fettes.  Come along now --
He links his arm through Fettes' and starts toward the do leading to the stairs. MACFARLANE (cont'd) -- let's get to the anatomy room -- I'll explain your new duties.
They have reached the door.  Meg is standing there.  As MacFarlane and Fettes start to pass her, Meg puts her han the doctor's arm.  He pauses.
A word with you, Dr. MacFarlane.
MacFarlane motions Fettes to proceed into the other room. closes the door behind him. MEG (cont'd) You're not having Fettes for your assistant?
And why not?  He's a good lad -- bright and able.
Aye.  He's a good lad.  That's why I ask you, MacFarlane.
You think it'll spoil the boy, eh?  Was I not assistant to Knox?
(thoughtfully) Aye --
Did it spoil me, Meg, my lass?

She looks directly at him without answering.  MacFarlane grows uneasy. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (walking up to her, putting an arm around her shoulders and tilting up her chin with his other hand) It will do the boy no harm.
He kisses her off-handedly.  She wraps her arm around his neck and kisses him with fierce passion.  He releases himself, goes on into the next room.

The anatomy room is dim.  Long level bars of light come through the wide windows to illuminate the bare austerity this classroom.  The long rows of tables have a sombre an empty look.  Everything is meticulously clean. At one of the tables is the hunched, dark and evil figure Joseph, the janitor of the school.  He is engaged in rubb the surface of a marble-topped table.  The door on the landing opens.  MacFarlane and Fettes come through.  MacFarlane still has his arm linked through that of his y friend and is listening to Fettes' gratitude with evident pleasure.
-- all my gratitude, sir -- I can never express it...
MED. FULL SHOT -- Fettes and MacFarlane as they descend t stairs.
(lightly) They'll be satisfaction enough for me to know I've trained the great Dr. Fettes.

MED. SHOT to include Joseph in the f.g. and Fettes and MacFarlane as they reach the floor level of the anatomy r Joseph, continuing his work, casts a sidelong glance at t doctor and student.  It is evident he is listening to eve word they say. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Now -- as to your duties.  It is up to you to keep the accounts and to distribute the specimens to the students.  Also, inasmuch as you'll be living in the house --
He looks over and glances at Joseph and having noticed th Joseph is eavesdropping, breaks off short. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (to Joseph) Joseph --
Joseph looks up. MACFARLANE (cont'd) What are you doing, sneaking about here like a Redskin?  Make a little noise, man.  Let people know you're about --
(meekly) Yes, Doctor -- yes.
-- otherwise I might get the idea you are trying to spy on me.
He takes Fettes' arm again and leads him off toward the o end of the anatomy room.  The two medicals go out of ears with Joseph in the f.g.

This is the small out-cropping of the main room set a few feet lower in level.  At one end is a heavy curtain of gr baize. MED. FULL SHOT.  MacFarlane and Fettes descend the steps leading to the alcove.  MacFarlane, with his hand on the elbow of the younger man, guides him to the curtain.
You know how we get the specimens we use for dissection?
From the Municipal Council -- they're the bodies of paupers --
The CAMERA BEGINS TO DOLLY SLOWLY TOWARD them.
That's what the law stipulates but there are not enough of them, Fettes -- there are not enough of them --
MacFarlane pulls aside the curtain.  He and Fettes pass through and the curtain falls into place behind them.  Th CAMERA CONTINUES TO TRUCK SLOWLY TOWARD the curtain.

CLOSE SHOT.  The little dog, Robbie, is lying on his mast grave.  He lies with his muzzle on his forepaws but his e are open and alert.  Out of the scene comes the plodding of a horse's hoofs and the rumbling of iron-shod wheels. dog lifts his head. The horse comes to a stop.  There is the creak of springs someone alights.  The dog's hackles rise.  He growls. ANOTHER ANGLE.  The great black shadow of a man in a cape overcoat and top hat with a spade over his shoulder is th onto the wall of Greyfriar's Kirk by the street lamp.  Th huge shadow looms high over the tiny dog.  Robbie rises valiantly to his feet, snarling.  As he does so, the actu figure of the man, as black and indistinct as his own sha comes past the camera, blacking out the little dog.  Ther a deeper growl from Robbie.  The man swings his spade dow As the spade drives home there is a little weak sound fro the dog. ANOTHER ANGLE.  With his foot, Gray pushes the dead body the little dog to one side, strikes the spade into the gr and starts to dig.

In a little attic room, Fettes is sleeping fitfully.  The room is flooded with moonlight which comes in through a skylight window. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes sleeping.  Far away can be hear the plodding hoofbeats and creaking wheels of Gray's cab. There is a loud squeak as the cab takes the turn into the alleyway.  Fettes wakens.  He listens.  There is a sound the hoofbeats, the wheels and then silence when the horse comes to a stop.  He sits up.  From downstairs comes a stealthy knocking at the door.  He gets up sleepily and starts to put on his worn bathrobe, crosses to the window looks out.
HIGH ANGLE SHOT from Fettes' window.  Gray, his cab and t white horse present a weird and funereal spectacle.  Gray fumbling with something inside the cab.
Fettes has turned from the window and starts toward the d He opens it and goes out.
Gray is pulling a long, canvas-colored object of consider weight from the cab.  With a grunt he gets it up into his arms and starts across the sidewalk toward the postern do

It is dark except for a small oil lamp left burning as a nightlight.  This casts its dim rays over a small portion the room near the entrance door.  Fettes comes through th door on the landing.  He peers over the bannisters and th somewhat slowly, as if not too easy at the prospect befor him, he begins to descend the stairs. ANOTHER ANGLE.  Fettes crosses the anatomy room looking apprehensively into the darkness at either end.  At the d he pauses a moment, then passes through into the darkness the entry and is lost to view.

It is so dark that Fettes can barely be seen.  The clank the chain as he throws it off and the snap of the bolt ar loud and frightening in this small enclosed space.  He pu the door open.  Before him silhouetted against the dim radiance of the cab lamps is Gray.  In his arms is a long cloth-covered object. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes as he opens the door wider to give G entrance.  Without a word, Gray carries the body past him into the anatomy room.  Fettes closes the door and follow him.
Gray comes in and stands waiting for Fettes to come up to him.  Fettes comes out of the entry and takes a few steps toward Gray.
Here -- give me a hand -- this is heavy.

Fettes helps him.  Gingerly he takes hold of the corpse a together they lay it down on a long marble-topped table i the center of the room, almost directly under the nightli Gray heaves a sigh of relief to be relieved of the weight GRAY (cont'd) You'll find the specimen in good condition.  He was bright and cheerful as a thrush not a week long gone.  A likely lad, I'm told. (glances at Fettes) You're the new assistant?
Fettes nods.
(trying to remember his manners) I'm Donald Fettes.
I'm very pleased to know you, Master Fettes.
Mr. Gray?
That's right.  Gray, the cabman.  I've had a bit of dealing with MacFarlane in the past, you know.
Fettes nods. GRAY (cont'd) And I've always gotten along with his assistants -- providing they understood my humble position.
He puts one hand on Fettes' arm.  Fettes moves away from
Dr. MacFarlane said I should pay you --
(interrupting) Of course -- it's the soul of the business -- the pay --
Fettes shifts uneasily, confused and seemingly uncertain his next step. GRAY (cont'd) (prompting him) I have no doubt you have the key in your pocket --
Fettes reaches into his pocket and brings out a big iron GRAY (cont'd) (pointing) And there is the box.
They start over toward it.  Fettes opens the box. GRAY (cont'd) My fee is as usual -- ten pounds.

Fettes counts out the money to him.  Gray flips the last into the air and catches it with a gamin gesture which is surprising in a man of such sinister appearance.  As Fett still stands rather stupidly, Gray prompts him again. GRAY (cont'd) And now, although it's none of my business, I would make the proper entry if I were you.  "One specimen -- ten pounds -- received from -- let us say -- "MacDuff" -- a royal name.
Fettes looks toward the desk. GRAY (cont'd) (still prompting him) It's the little cloth-covered book in the drawer.
Fettes brings it out.  Gray watches him while he writes. pen scratches and squeaks over the paper.  Then both turn start toward the entry.
Good night, Mr. Gray.
As the door Gray tips his hat elegantly to Fettes.
My respects, Master Fettes, and may this be the first of many profitable meetings.

He leaves, disappearing in the darkness of the entryway. second later the door can be heard closing behind him.  Fettes stands for a long moment looking at the dark entry then from behind him comes a chuckle of laughter.  He whi abruptly. ANOTHER ANGLE -- Fettes in the b.g. and above him on the landing, holding a candle, is Dr. MacFarlane in an elegan dressing gown.
Well, well, my boy.  Your first meeting with the redoubtable Gray.  You may count it as a milestone in your medical career.
MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes as he looks from MacFarlane to door.
My medical career --

CLOSE SHOT -- skeleton.  It is facing the camera, its sta a parody of that prize fighter of the period; left well extended, right held high, both knees bent.  Over the sho comes a clamor of men's voices, cutting across which, suddenly, comes Fettes' voice.
All right, gentleman -- that will do!  Settle down!

The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the interior of the school. the f.g. is the dais, at one side of which is the skeleto Fettes steps up onto the dais at the other side of the passing some dozen students, all young men in their early twenties.  Two students, Gilchrist and Richardson, are prominent.  Richardson is lean and sardonic. FETTES (cont'd) Dr. MacFarlane has asked me to review the points he has just discussed with you.

MED. CLOSE SHOT -- dais.  The skeleton is to one side in f.g. facing the students, o.s.  Fettes has his back to it FETTES (cont'd) He started with the construction of the ribs and the haemapophyses --
He turns toward the skeleton, then reacts sharply as he notices its ludicrous stance. FETTES (cont'd) (angrily) I suppose this was your doing, Richardson.
He starts rearranging the skeleton's limbs.  Richardson grins.  It is at this moment that Joseph comes sidling up the group.
Mr. Fettes --
Fettes looks over at him. JOSEPH (cont'd) A lady is asking for you.
What lady, Joseph?
Joseph shrugs.  Fettes, seeing that he'll get no enlightenment from him, turns to the students. FETTES (cont'd) If you gentleman will excuse me --
He starts for the stairs.  There is a snicker of laughter Richardson leans over and with two deft movements brings arms of the skeleton back into fighting position.
Mrs. Marsh sits there.  Broad beams of sunlight flood in the front windows.  She is speaking with Meg Cameron.  Me standing looking down at her.
Why do you come here?  The Doctor said he wouldn't operate.
I've already told you I didn't come to see Dr. MacFarlane.
Then whom do you wish to see in MacFarlane's own house?

It is at this moment that the door opens and Fettes comes Meg takes one glance at him. MEG (cont'd) (almost under her breath) So it is in that direction that the wind blows, eh?  It will get you nothing.
With that she turns on her heel and goes off to a little on the left.
(rising) Good morning, Mr. Fettes.
Fettes bows formally.  It is obvious he is pleased, yet v puzzled to see her.  He comes down and takes her hand.
You asked to see me, ma'am?
(impulsively) I want you to help my little girl.
I'm only a student.
Georgina told me how kind you were to her.  It gave me hope you might intercede for us with Dr. MacFarlane.
I don't know that I can do that, Mrs. Marsh.
Did he tell you about Georgina?
Fettes nods. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) Then he must have told you that this disease is progressive -- that it will grow worse -- that soon she will not be able to move at all.
Fettes nods again.  Mrs. Marsh lays her hand on his arm a looks directly into his eyes. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) And you won't ask him to help?
I didn't mean it that way.  I meant only that I am not in a position to ask favors.
Ask this one favor --
(very much moved) Of course I will.
Mrs. Marsh smiles at him.
Georgina was right.  You are a kind man.
She extends her hand and Fettes takes it.
I'll do what I can.
He walks with her to the door, lets her out, closes it be her and then turns and starts back the way he came.

MacFarlane is present and now in contrast to the disorder under Fettes the students are busy and absorbed.  They ar working at their tasks.  MacFarlane, with two or three ar him, is helping one of the students, Gilchrist.

That brought him close to Gray, he roistered with him and drank with him. Aye, and Gray even brought him to my door and my love. There is all that between them and more -- Burke and Hare and Knox --
But that's long since.  Gray can't threaten him with that.
Gray has no need to threaten. You remember the trial?
I heard my parents speak of it in Thrums. It was a famous case.
And did you hear them speak of the porter who testified against Burke?
Aye.
They did not tell you how that porter cried out in the witness box when the Kings Counselor pressed him hard -- how he cried out that he was shielding a gentleman of consequence.
Fettes shakes his head.
That porter was Gray and the gentleman of consequence who couldn't swallow the shame of it -- who took my last paltry savings to hire Gray --
MacFarlane
They stand for a moment looking at each other then she tu wildly toward Fettes and seizes his coat lapels.

Listen to me, Fettes, I'm one part befuddled with drink, one part over-heels in love with MacFarlane, and one part fey. You're a lowlander, Fettes, and you have no way of knowing what we Highlanders call the second sight.
I've heard of it.
It's a gift to my people -- and I see MacFarlane and Gray-- the pit yawns for them and the flames -- and I would have you away from them and safe out of the torment.--
The two stand facing each other, Meg crushing the boy's c lapels in her hands.

It is very dark as Gray opens the door. For a moment his distinctive silhouette is in the doorway. Then he closes door behind him and the room is again plunged into darkne except for a glow from the embers in the hearth. Gray cro to the hearth. He takes a spill from the mantle, blows on coals and lights the spill. Its flaring light reveals MacFarlane standing watching him. After a first momentary check of surprise, Gray, without a word, transfers the fl from the spill to a candle.  He blows out the spill and s it back on the mantle. MED. SHOT with Gray in the f.g. and MacFarlane coming tow him. Gray has recovered his composure.
(very softly) This is unexpected, Toddy.
MacFarlane comes to a halt facing Gray. The CAMERA BEGINS CHEAT IN ON the pair.
(toneless) I wanted to see you. You weren't here -- so I waited.

The two men survey each other in absolute silence. From o near at hand, the cat mews. The CAMERA PULLS BACK TO SLIGHTLY WIDER ANGLE as Gray tur away, seating himself upon the arm of a chair. The cat co into the shot and jumps up beside him.
(drawing closer) What do you want of me. Gray?
(smiling) Want of you, Toddy? I want nothing of you.

TWO SHOT - Gray and MacFarlane.  MacFarlane is tense, motionless. He stares down at Gray who sits at his ease stroking the cat, now purring on his knee. MacFarlane makes an obvious effort to control himself, to speak calmly.
Gray, I must rid myself of you -- you've become a cancer -- a malignant, evil cancer -- rotting my mind.
(pouring a drink for MacFarlane) So, Toddy, you've made me a disease, eh?
(disregarding this sarcasm, but taking the proffered glass) I can't understand your hurt to me -- but I must cut you out.
He drinks, sets down the glass. Gray watches him, gets up from his chair and stands before him.
I will not leave here until I have finished with you. Gray. One way or another -- I must be sure that I am rid of you.
He pauses and looks at Gray.
And if there is no other way --
Gray looks at MacFarlane, big and bulky in the small chai He moves nervously.
Surely you are not threatening an old friend, Toddy.
We have never been friends.
Gray moves over to the chair on which he sat when he "Bur Joseph. He bends forward over the taboret and refills the doctor's glass.
Have another glass of something good, Toddy.
I've drunk enough tonight.
(putting the glass down on the taboret) Another little drop'll never do you any harm.

Almost as if unconscious of his action, MacFarlane picks the glass, sips, then drinks. Gray smiles. MacFarlane set down the glass. Gray immediately refills it. And again MacFarlane reaches for it, takes it into his hand.
(softly) Drink --
MacFarlane, without thought, brings the glass to his lips
You're getting old, Gray, and it's a hard life driving a cab through these wet and windy streets of Edinburgh --
I have other means of sustenance.
The Resurrection business? That may end sooner than you think. New laws may come.
Gray shrugs.
What I was going to say is this -- wouldn't you be more comfortable at Leith in a neat little house?
Would you bribe me to leave you be?
I would make you rich.
It wouldn't be half so much fun for me. Toddy, as to have you come here and beg --
(cutting in) Beg -- beg of you! You crawling graveyard rat!
He chokes off the last speech and glares at Gray. He is almost trembling with the effort to control himself.
Aye -- that is my pleasure.
As he speaks he is refilling MacFarlane's glass.
Well then -- I beg you -- I beseech you --
(shaking, his head and grinning) But then I wouldn't have the fun of having you come here and beg again, Toddy.
They look at each other. MacFarlane bends over in his cha Gray hitches himself forward a little on the table, ready waiting, then relaxes as MacFarlane begins to speak.
But why, Gray? Why?
Because it would be a hurt to me to see you no more, Toddy. You're a pleasure to me.
A pleasure to torment me?

No -- a pride to know that I can force you to my will. I'm a small man -- a humble man -- and being poor, I've had to do much that I did not want to do. But so long as the great Dr. MacFarlane jumps at my whistle, that long am I a man -- and if I have not that, I have nothing. Then I am only a cabman and a grave-robber.

MacFarlane looks at him.  As he looks, he realizes he has heard the truth and that Gray will never leave him in pea Now he, in turn, attempts cunning.  He moves forward in h chair as if wishing to put forth a convincing argument.  MacFarlane starts to rise; his mind made up. Gray sees th is no longer any hope of forestalling violence. He throws himself forward and seizes him as he seized Joseph.  MED. FULL SHOT - MacFarlane and Gray. As MacFarlane rises Gray clings to him and gets his other arm about MacFarlan neck. MacFarlane tries to shake him off; tries to twist a from him. The effort makes him lose his footing.  They fa together.  CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane and Gray on the floor near the hearth.  Gray still clings to him, every muscle tense. MacFarlane, with his hands under Gray's shoulders, heaves trying to push the man off. He heaves once, twice, a thir time and then lets his arms relax from the futile, enormo effort.  TWO HEAD CLOSEUP - Gray and MacFarlane.
Let be, Toddy.  Let be. I have no wish to hurt you.

MacFarlane's eyes grow huge and fierce with anger. Now he tries to pummel Gray in order to free himself; raining bl on his back, his head and into his side, Gray grunts with each punishing blow, but never for a moment relaxes his g Finally the piston-like blows grow weaker, the flailing a fail and MacFarlane drops his hands to the floor at his s limp and relaxed.  MED. CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane and Gray as MacFarlane, wit great effort, throws his body to the left, toward the fireplace.  The boiling kettle is upset and the steaming water thrown on both of them.  CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane in agony as the water spurts ove him.  CLOSE SHOT -- Gray. His face is twisted in torment and st rises from his scalded flesh.
Stay, Toddy -- don't force me to kill you -- I have need of you -- the great need of my pride.
TWO SHOT -- Gray and MacFarlane.  MacFarlane's arms again relax.  Gray smiles through the pain of his scalding.
That's better Toddy. That's more reasonable,

He lets go his grip on MacFarlane's face.  No sooner has done so than MacFarlane throws him off with a violent movement. Both men scramble to their feet and face each other. THE CAMERA SWINGS AWAY FROM the two men and FOCUSES ON th wall above a lowboy on which the white cat is sitting. Th cat's great, round eyes seem to be surveying the struggle while above its head the shadows of the two men can be se meeting, struggling, breaking off, rushing together again and all the while there can be heard the sound of blows, hoarse breathing, gasps and hard ejaculations of breath. one indistinguishable figure picks up a chair. The chair breaks with a crash over the head of the other figure and that figure falls out of scene. Only one upright shadow remains above the head of the cat. That shadow picks up a cloak and top hat, puts them on and bends to pick up a bo The shadow of one man carrying the body of the other come toward the cat, the shadow growing huge and out-figure on wall. The cat's fur bristles. It arches its back and snar

Only the night light is burning over the door at the entr way. The school is lit by its swinging light. Out in the street can be heard the familiar clop-clop of Gray's horse and the ringing of the iron wheels on the roadway.  The CAMERA on DOLLY TRACK MOVES SLOWLY TOWARD the entry d The outer door can be heard opening. There is rustle and noise in the dark entryway. By this time the CAMERA is CLOSEUP on the door as MacFarlane with a canvas-wrapped bundle on his shoulder comes through the doorway, and goe a FULL CLOSEUP of his face. He starts forward.  MED. FULL SHOT - MacFarlane as he throws the body down on the table. He stands there for a moment looking down at i then the noise of a door opening on the stair landing cau him to turn and look up. MED. FULL SHOT - the stairway.  Meg is seen at the head o the stairs, looking down.  ANOTHER ANGLE - MacFarlane is seen from Meg's viewpoint.
Where is Fettes?
MED. FULL SHOT - the stairway as Meg begins to descend.
He's gone. I sent him away. I'll not see another boy harried and torn and made miserable like you, Toddy.
MacFarlane looks at her as she descends the stairs. There silence as she crosses the room. She comes to stand besid the table.
(pointing to the bundle) You've been with Gray again.
Aye.
Meg turns away as if to start for the stairs.  He stops h
You'd better look at the face.
She looks at him.
You'd, better.
Meg resolutely walks up to the table, lifts the canvas an looks down at the face.
I'm rid of him forever.
Meg looks at him.
He'll not come here again -- sneaking and whining and bullying.
Meg is still silent.
Now he'll serve a good purpose -- and tomorrow when the last bit of him is dissected, demonstrated and detailed in the students' notebooks, then at last there's an end to him.
Meg still looks at him silently and thoughtfully, then wi slight shake of her head she starts away.

(rubbing his hands together) Next day I'll take his horse and cab to sell at the Pennycuick fair. (pauses; then makes an expansive movement with his hands) Then not a trace left -- rid of him forever.
At the foot of the stairs, Meg turns to him.
You're not rid of him.

A little boy rolling a hoop goes past the camera. Behind come running a little convoy of children, laughing and shouting. When they have passed the camera, Fettes enters scene. He is dejected. His hands are in his pockets and h head is down as he walks toward Georgina and her mother. Georgina is in her wheelchair. Her head is turned as she watches the children run out of sight.
Good morning, Mrs. Marsh.
Good morning, Mr. Fettes.
I thought this was a school day.
I am not at the school anymore. I left last night.
Mrs. Marsh looks at him.
Left Dr. MacFarlane?
Fettes nods. Mrs. Marsh looks at him and then takes his elbow.
(to Georgina) Play by yourself a little. I'd like' to speak to Mr. Fettes.
DOLLY SHOT - as Fettes and Mrs. Marsh walk slowly away fr Georgina.
This is serious, Donald. What has happened?
Fettes shakes his head.
It's not because of Georgina -- because of Dr. MacFarlane's failure?
It's not the failure. I feel that MacFarlane has taught me nothing. He taught me the mathematics of anatomy but he couldn't teach me the poetry of medicine.

MED. FULL SHOT -- Georgina. She is playing with her doll. Suddenly, from far below her she hears the clop-clop of a horse's hoofs and the rumble of iron wheels. She looks up listens.  MED. FULL SHOT - Fettes and Mrs. Marsh.

That's why I don't want to go on. I feel MacFarlane had me on the wrong road --a road that led to knowledge but not to healing. If there had been any healing in the man, Georgina would be walking now.
SHOT - Georgina. She is listening intently. The hoof beat are right underneath her at the base of the castle wall. tries to look over the parapet; cannot. She calls out.
Mommie! Mommie!

FULL SHOT - Mrs. Marsh and Fettes. They are talking inten together. Mrs. Marsh is holding her parasol in such a way that it is between her and Georgina.  Georgina's call com very faintly over their conversation. Neither of then tur toward the child.
I think it was the pain of the operation more than anything else -- she's afraid that if she stands the pain will come again. Nothing Dr. MacFarlane could ever do would take that out of her mind.
CLOSE SHOT - Georgina. The hoof beats are beginning to recede. There is a slight wind blowing. She turns around look at her mother and calls again.
Mommie!  Mommie!

There is no answer. She turns her head back toward the battlements; tries to peer over them and fails. Then, pla a hand on each arm of her little chair, she lifts herself a sort of standing-sitting position. She tries to look ov the wall again. Again she fails. She turns to call to her mother.
Mommie -- the white horse -- I'm sure it's the white horse --
MED. CLOSE SHOT - Fettes and Mrs. Marsh.
Even so, I could never think of going on -- I've got to find some other profession.
It is a pity.

SHOT - Georgina. She has gotten herself to the same semi erect position she had been before and now in her despera effort to see over the battlement, she suddenly straighte her knees; her hands lift off the arms of the chair. With knowing it, she is standing. She tries again to look over wall and again the height and distance is too much for he Completely unconscious of what she is doing, she takes a forward step and from this vantage point she can look ove the wall. She turns back with disappointment on her face. calls to her mother.
Mommie! It was another horse.

CLOSE FULL SHOT -- Fettes and Mrs. Marsh with the child i the b.g. They see the child standing. Mrs. Marsh makes a wordless exclamation of joy.  She doesn't even dare to mo for fear this might be a vision.  ANOTHER ANGLE -- Fettes, Mrs. Harsh and Georgina. Mrs. Ma and Fettes run in. CLOSE FULL SHOT-- of the three.
You're standing, Georgina.
The child looks down, sees that she is standing and almos instantly grabs at the chair for support.  Very gently Fe pulls it away.
You'll not need that again, Georgina.
(excited and almost in tears) I wanted to see the white horse --

Fettes and Mrs. Marsh kneel down close to the child. Mrs. Marsh takes her into her arms. Fettes rises to his feet, face is full of enthusiasm and excitement. His voice trem with the keenness of accomplishment.
(wildly excited) I've got to tell Dr. MacFarlane. I've got to tell him.
There is the ringing of a doorbell. Meg comes down the stairs.  She crosses the hall and opens the door. Fettes stands there. Meg holds the door open for him to enter an closes it behind him.
Mistress Cameron -- you'll not believe it, but the child has walked -- stood and walked. I must tell Dr. MacFarlane.
He starts forward as if to go on into the study. Meg stop him with her hand on his arm.
He's not home.
Where can I find him?
You don't went to find him. Your news will keep until I tell him.
But I must tell him -- he must know of it. Please -- tell me where he is.

There's no standing between a fool and his folly. If you must babble your news to him he's at the Fisherman's Tryst. It's the inn at Pennycuik. You can use MacFarlane's horse and gig to get there. He'll welcome the ride back.
(already starting to turn; still very much excited) At Pennycuik.  I know the inn.  I can be there in an hour.
(bitterly) And back with MacFarlane and all that he stands for the next day.
She opens the door for Fettes and closes it after him.

It is a long, low-raftered room with a fire of logs burni on the hearth. Outside the wind can be heard blowing and shrilling.  A considerable company has gathered for warmt and food.  MED. CLOSE SHOT -- an amiable rustic, a horse dealer, who stands, booted with whip in hand, talking to several fell bumpkins while the maidservant of the inn serves them ale from a large wooden tray. Their wet clothes are steaming the heat of the fire.
A sound horse and a closed carriage -- and after I'd talked with him a bit I had his price down to four pounds and then.
He laughs.
And worth every bit or ten pounds.
He lifts a tankard from the tray.
Surely, Angus, a man who had won so great a victory in a horse deal would buy the poor loser a drink.
(taking it big as he throws a coin onto the tray) Take him a pot of ale.
Ale for a Gentleman? It's only French brandy he'd be drinking, and that will be two more shillings, Angus.

Very reluctantly Angus takes out the additional money. Th girl starts out of scene and the CAMERA PANS WITH her to MacFarlane seated at a small table at the other side of t hearth.  He has just finished dinner and is pushing his p away from him.  The maidservant comes up to him.
The man who bought your horse would like you to have a glass of French brandy at his charge.
Now that's very civil of him.

At the other side of the hearth the louts around the hors dealer strike up a song.  Outside there is the sound of a horse clattering into the courtyard, then the muffled sho as the driver reins the horse in and the hostler goes to head.  Both MacFarlane and the maidservant listen and loo toward the door.  The door swings open and Fettes stands there, his clothes drenched with rain.  As he enters, he shakes the water from his hat.  He sees MacFarlane and go over to him quickly, excited and smiling.
Doctor -- the little Marsh girl stood and walked -- really stood and walked --
MacFarlane makes way for Fettes on the settle -- Fettes s down quickly.
What's that you say?
The little girl -- she couldn't walk far -- the muscles are too weak -- but she did stand and she took a step or two.
(very excited) I know it -- I know it -- The moment I was rid of him --
What?
Gray -- I'm rid of him --
Fettes looks at him, puzzled.
(guarding his thoughts) Just that -- just that -- I've managed to get him to leave Edinburgh -- he'll bother me no more.
He rubs his hands together. The maidservant has returned with a bottle of brandy and glasses. MacFarlane pours one for himself and Fettes.
Drink.
Fettes picks up his glass.
Here's to a good riddance.
They both drink.
Now that he's gone I'll be a new man, Fettes, and a better teacher. The doctors from my school will perform miracles --

The door opens and a party of five people dressed in roug mourning come in out of the weather. The maidservant, wit show of solicitude, ushers them to a table at the far end the inn, then crosses quickly to where the horse dealer i
Sh-h-h! Still your song, lads -- the MacCreadys are here and they've come from burying the old woman in Glencorse Kirkyard.
They stop singing and look over with sympathetic glances the burial party.  MED. CLOSE SHOT - Fettes and MacFarlane.  MacFarlane look from the boys around the fire to the burial party.
See that, Fettes?
A burial party -- poor people -- it's hard to bury a loved one on a rainy day when the churchyard is so cold and lonely.
Glencorse -- that's a lonely cemetery, Fettes, not a soul around for miles.
They'll be thinking of that, too.
Tosh!  Fettes!  It's not their grief I'm worrying about -- I'm talking of our own end --
You've no thought of going there?
Did you think Gray was the only one who could handle a mattock and shovel?  I've had some practice in the art.
(protesting) You couldn't do that, Doctor.
(rising) I pass up no opportunities, I've a whole course of lectures in mind for you fellows.  We'll need subjects to demonstrate. Come along.
No.

Why not? I must have subjects. It's the only way I can teach. It's the only way you can learn. The stupidity of the people the idiocy of their laws will not stop no -- nor will they force me to deal with such reptilian creatures as Gray. We can do our own dirty work -- and we must.
Fettes shakes his head. MacFarlane starts for the door an after a little pause, Fettes rises and follows him.

FULL SHOT. The thunder increases in volume throughout the scene.  In extreme b.g. two figures can be seen intermittently. CLOSE SHOT - grave. The headstone is brand new but the mo beneath it has been demolished, leaving a ragged gaping h A spade comes down into picture with vicious force.  As i raised with its burden of earth:
(triumphant) So we can't do without Mister Gray  - So I'd never be rid of him, eh?
CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane and Fettes as they work over the grave. MacFarlane's spade thumps against wood.
A-ah!

He jumps down into the grave, the CAMERA TILTING DOWN CUT OUT Fettes.  MacFarlane is levering up the edge of the co with his spade.  As the wood gives, there is a tremendous clap of thunder immediately overhead, followed by a solid deluge of rain.

MED. FULL SHOT. The storm is raging. In the f.g. is MacFarlane's carriage, the horse tethered to the fence. Whickering, intensely nervous, he is looking o.s. toward cemetery. Shuffling footsteps come over shot and the hors fear increases.  MED. SHOT - at side of carriage is MacFarlane and Fettes into scene carrying a heavy burden, wrapped in canvas.
(hoarsely) Where shall we put it? In the back?
No room there. We'll have to set it between us.

FULL SHOT - The storm is continuing unabated. A narrow, twisting road runs down the hillside, and the terrain is desolate and rocky. Horse's hooves are heard and MacFarla carriage comes into the scene, going down the hill.

CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane. He is driving, his head thrust forward to see the road. The CAMERA PANS, VERY SLIGHTLY t show what is next to him; something wrapped in a thin she of canvas; something which sits limply; something which s the unmistakable shape of a human body beneath its coveri It is held by Fettes' hand which is just in shot. The CAM PANS again to show Fettes. His teeth are clenched; his ey closed.  MED. SHOT - showing both men and the thing between them. horse is trotting fast and as the carriage turns a bend, thing lunges heavily against MacFarlane's shoulder.
(savagely) Keep it off me, will you!
FULL SHOT - Still the storm - even fiercer. MacFarlane's carriage, the horse galloping, comes down the hill, swayi and lurching. The pace is much too fast for the going.
MED. SHOT. It is very dark. MacFarlane is hauling at the reins with all his strength.
(savage) What's got into this animal!

CLOSE SHOT - Fettes. He is still holding the thing o.s.  THREE SHOT. The carriage sways violently and the thing between the men, its outlines barely distinguishable, see to twist out of Fettes' grip. It sags against MacFarlane.
Keep it off me!
Forced to keep both hands on the reins, MacFarlane tries thrust the thing away with his shoulder. But it still kee falling against him.
(shouting) Keep it off me, I say!

Fettes makes an effort to hold on to the corpse. MED. FULL SHOT -- the carriage going along the road; the horse proceeding at a hard trot. The hoof beats ring out rhythmically.  THREE SHOT -- PROCESS -- Fettes, MacFarlane and the corps The rhythmic hoof beats sound very loud as the two men dr on in silence. Fettes makes a desperate effort to hold th corpse away from MacFarlane, but it keeps bumping into th doctor.  Through the hoof beats and in the same rhythm co the voice of Gray on the sound track.
You'll not get rid of me that way -- that way -- that way -- that way --

MacFarlane shakes his head as if to clear it of this remembered voice;  these well-remembered words.  CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane.  His eyes are wide with apprehension and fear.  He glances down at the wrapped co as it bumps against him. He draws away, shivering. Over t sound track Gray's voice still sounds beating on the ear the same rhythm as the hoofs on the road.  MacFarlane pul up on the reins.  THREE SHOT - as MacFarlane turns to Fettes the carriage c to a halt.
(making an effort to arrive at speech) Fettes -- for Mercy's sake, let's have a light!
Fettes looks over at his companion. He has never seen MacFarlane in this state before and the younger man is puzzled.
All right.

He climbs over the sill into the roadway.  MED. FULL SHOT - the carriage as Fettes tries to strike a light in the pouring rain and howling wind. He finally ge taper going and touches it to the lamp wick. The lamp fla for a moment.  TWO SHOT -- MacFarlane and the corpse.
It's changed!  I swear it! It's changed, Fettes!
REVERSE SHOT - Fettes as he looks up puzzled.
Changed? Changed, to what?
HIGH ANGLE SHOT - MacFarlane and the corpse with Fettes a lower level.
Let's have that lamp.
Fettes undoes it from the dashboard and lifts it up over head to cast a light on the corpse.
(looking down at the bundle) This is not a woman!
(matter-of-factly) It was a woman when we put her in.
(somewhat wildly) Hold that lamp up -- I must see her face.

He tears open the sacking. ANOTHER ANGLE - CLOSE SHOT of Fettes.  He is looking up holding the lantern high over his head, but is unable to anything over the high dashboard except MacFarlane's face Suddenly, MacFarlane pulls back and on his face there is a look of anguish and terror that Fettes cries out in ala
Dr. MacFarlane?

REVERSE SHOT - Now the face of the dead woman can be seen with MacFarlane looking down at it in horror as slowly it turns to the dark, well-moulded features and smooth-shave cheeks of the familiar countenance of Gray. A wild yell breaks from MacFarlane's lips.
Gray -- Gray --

MED. FULL SHOT - the horse and carriage. The nervous hors bolts. Fettes tries to dodge out of the way. The lamp fal and breaks and in the darkness the carriage goes bounding past his and away. He stands looking after it, then break into a run, following the runaway. CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane.  He is fighting to control the horse.  But, as the carriage rocks, the thing against his shoulder moves; either by reason of the violent motion or some frightful volition of its own.  The canvas wrapping slips, slides away and reveals again head and naked torso of Gray.  The pace increases even more. MacFarlane sees the dreadfu metamorphosis and a strangled cry breaks from his throat. The carriage sways again and the arms come free from the canvas. Another swerve, another lurch and they have falle limply around MacFarlane's neck.

FULL SHOT - a hairpin turn, with cliff-wall to one side, sheer drop to the other. The carriage, the horse beyond control, cannot take it at the speed. It strikes the clif wheel breaks loose, the braces tear apart, the horse staggers, runs on free, the carriage tilts sickeningly, stands on end, rolls over the edge and plunges down to destruction.

Fettes has managed to get the lamp going again and is run along the road, following the wheel tracks in the rain-so earth. He comes upon a bit of wreckage and stops. He list then walks over to the edge of the cliff. He holds his lantern well over the edge and peers down. Then he starts down the cliff side.

MED. FULL SHOT - Fettes as he scrambles down, holding the lantern at arm's length to protect it from the rough rock and the heather.  He comes to a slightly more level space stops. He looks down.  MED. SHOT - SHOOTING DOWNWARD FROM Fettes' viewpoint. MacFarlane's body, obviously without life, is lying flat its back, arms and legs outspread. And, lying against his chest, is something wrapped in canvas. The CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY DOWN UNTIL IT IS CLOSE, showing beyond all doubt that not only has the canvas never been disturbed, but also that it is the woman's body which it covers.
